the third option is you can host your database with relational database
service which is provided provided by AWS and that service is called la dias
to understand the defense between these three options then you host your

you still have control over your patching at what time you want your patches to be applied but everything is

it's no secret that if we do although all the things in Orange manually that

advantage of Amazon RDS so with RDS you

for running the database for 10 hours so on this platform we have six different
database engines we have mysql pascua sequel amazon aurora which we will talk
about today we have Maria DB sequel server and oracle so a good question at
this point might be well if we already have so many database engines on our platform why did we build RDS by did we
build amazon Aurora specifically so when we started working on Amazon Aurora
earlier this decade our customers consistently came to us and asked us to
bridge the gap between commercial database engines and open source database engines right our customers
told us that sorry our customers told us that they wanted speed and availability
of high-end commercial database engines but they wanted simplicity and cost-effectiveness of open source
databases right and while we are doing that didn't want us to create a
completely new database interface because if we create a new sequel language or database interface they will
have to go and learn that so they wanted drop in compatibility with a famous or
popular open source database in jail like my sequel and just like other are
deep RDS databases they wanted simple pay-as-you-go pricing and they wanted that database as a as a managed service
so you can imagine in order to deliver on these asks we had to do significant
innovation in traditional database attack because
database stack hasn't changed a lot in last 30 years right these are some
different architectures database architectures that we see right now so we have a shorting architecture where
you shot your database across multiple machines and you maintain that shouting logic on your application layer which is
error prone and requires you to do more work you have shared nothing architecture where you separate the data
on different machines and the data separation is managed by the database engine itself you don't have to write
code for that the issue with these architectures is that now you're since
your data is spread across multiple machines if one of the machine fails you lose access to that data right so your
availability goes down as you increase the number of nodes in that architecture and then you have shared disk
architecture where you are sharing the storage across multiple nodes but then
you have hot key issues and distributed locking issues with those databases and not to mention shared nothing and shared
disk architectures which are provided by commercial database vendors these software's are really really expensive
and very few companies are able to use those softwares in their production
systems so a common thing in all these architectures is we still have sequel
transaction caching and logging layer these are the four layers of database engines tightly coupled on the same box
right so and even when we are scaling we are scaling the same layers in different
architecture so we didn't really changed a lot in last 30 years when it comes to
traditional database architectures so to improve on that and to deliver on what
our customers were asking us for be radically changed the database
architecture in Aurora so Aurora is my sequel 5.6 compatible database you have
drop in compatibility and to give the performance that our customers were
asking for be completely separated out the logging and storage layer outside
the database smocks so the green box that you see there it's a purpose-built storage layer
that understands database logs and it can convert database logs into database pages so now your sequel and transaction
layer is not responsible for genetic database pages and that's how we are able to reduce the i/o going from
database machine to the storage layer because now storage layer is intelligent it understands database logs it's not a
dumb device we also integrated Aurora with s3 now since we had advantage of
AWS scale architecture we had advantage advantage of services like DynamoDB simple workflow service route 53 we
integrated these services with Amazon Aurora so for example your backups are
continuously streamed to s 3 and s 3 gives you 11 lines of durability out of
the box and I'll talk about that a little bit more by the way there is a

different industry is CS is an insurance claims processing company that does

they were actually using Oracle and sequel server for their operational and

play they got some other advantages out of it too they eliminated their backup window which we will talk about that you
don't have a backup window in Aurora they not almost linear scaling as their

aurora is simple performance I think alfresco shared with us that they found
Aurora to be ten times more performant than their existing my sequel databases
and ten times is a huge performance jump right by any standards so let's take a
look at some of the raw performance numbers when we ran a cyst bench test on
our biggest of OtterBox are 38 extra large machine with 32 cores and 244 gig
of ram this is the performance we got we got about 100,000 writes per second and
we were making 4,000 connections in this case from four different client machines and read performance we got a little bit
less than six hundred thousand per second and this was with 1600 threads
this performance is about five times the performance of regular my sequel on the
same hardware and with the same setup now you may say that well you know real
world applications are not sis bench tests and you know of course you can get
good results in sis bench I need to hold these slides so you can get good results
with sis bench but what happens in real world scenarios so in order to debunk
that myth we actually ran tests in Aurora that different conditions and
what we found was and what our customers also find is that Aurora performs really
well significantly better than my sequel under different conditions so when
the things that you will notice when you start using aurora is that your performance increases as your number of
connections increases and that's probably counterintuitive for a lot of us right usually we don't see
performance increasing the number of connections increases the Aurora you can throw thousands of connections at the
database I think the test that we ran one of the tests that we dan was with 5,000 connections and you performance
scales linearly as the number of connections increase to the database system if you increase your tables from
let's say hundred cables to 10,000 tables your performance remains consistent if you grow your data set
from few gigabytes to let's say few hundred gigabytes your performance remains consistent so under varying
conditions we we saw our order to hold up really well against my sequel one of
the another critical piece features of Aurora is very low replication lag it's
virtually negligible so one of the problems in my sequel is if you are
running your master database which isn't that heavy right your read replicas or your slave databases can lag behind by
few seconds or minutes depending on the right activity on your master database and that's really a problem if you have
many applications that are running reporting workloads from from the slave databases in aurora due to the
architecture changes that we have made in the database that replica leg doesn't exist so even with 10,000 updates per
second on the master database we saw about five milliseconds of replica lag between master database and the slave
database the read replica which is a huge improvement over any any other
database system so performance was great our customers love that but our
customers also told us that well if performance only matters then I can keep
my database up and running right so we did a lot of innovation behind the
scenes in Aurora to give you a very high availability and reliability in the database system
so let's talk about storage the underlying storage piece when you host
your databases in your data centers how do you make your storage highly available right now you probably
replicate your storage at the storage layer from one data center to another data center or you do replication on the
database layer like if you are doing my sequel you will do build or application if you are doing Oracle you will do log
shipping or you will do Data Guard something like that right that's not the case in Aurora even when you are just
using a database in one availability zone one data center we make six copies
of your data across three physically isolated data centers and this is what
we call availability zone so let's say that you host a database in our North Virginia region we have multiple
availability zones in that region VEVO as soon as you make a right to the
database your right is getting replicated across six different storage nodes across three physically separated
data centers right so that's a that's a huge advantage in terms of high
availability if one of the data center goes down your data is still there you still have access to that data if you
have read replicas in that availability zone you can switch over to your be dropped across right away which system
will actually do it for you it will do automatic failover for you and you will get access to your data right away with
this storage architecture we also use a latency tolerant gorham system so let's
say I have six discs and i'm writing to those discs chances are that one or two discs might be running slow right it's
hardware it's just discard where we use four by six gorham for rights so that as
as soon as we get confirmation from four disks we confirm the right back to the user so if two of my desks are running
slow that doesn't really slow down my whole database and we use 3 by 6 khodam for for weeds for the same purpose now
that this storage architecture we can also have up to 15 read replicas across
the whole region in one or all our cluster you can have one mass database and 15v drop lockers and these
rude replicas are as good as your master database because there is virtually no replication lag so you can really scale
your reads over those read replicas one
of the things we also did on caching layer was we separated the caching process outside the main database
process so typically in databases what happens is if there is a deadlock or if
there is any other condition your database process process crashes then your database process crashes and then
it comes back up your cash also needs to be warmed up at that time you will draw and select queries to warm up your
caches in this case since we have a different caching process on the same box if the database engine krasic
crushes that doesn't really crash my cash so my database injured comes back
up my cache is still warm and I can resume my fully loaded operations very quickly so I don't really have to run
any select queries to warm up my cash and that's a really important feature for many organizations that that need
quick availability and high availability for their systems now if the whole
database box crashes the crash recovery itself is also instantaneous in case of
my sequel and many of the databases the way crash recovery happens is you have database logs database comes back up it
will replay those logs in a single threaded transaction and then those logs are replayed you get your database in
case of Aurora we just don't do any crash recovery as soon as database comes
back up we make it available to the user and then users will fire some queries to
the database when users send their queries to the database at that time we
replay the logs in our storage layer which is a normal part of the Aurora operation we replay logs and we convert
those logs into database pages on demand and we serve those pages to the user so the crash recovery the concept of crash
recovery itself is parallel distributed and asynchronous so you don't have to wait for like five minutes ten minutes
half an hour for your database to covered from Akash we also recently
added support for cross region read replicas so if you are running an aura
cluster in let's say North Virginia region you wanted a read replica in
Oregon region you can now do that automatically with Amazon Aurora you can
click few buttons and create a new replica so that will help you with disaster recovery situations it will
also let you bring data close to your users if you have a big user base invest ghost or any other part of the world and
you wanted that low latency between that
so just like other a tubular services vanaf our design intent was to make it really easy for use for our customers so

because adding storage on the fly may have performance implications it requires human intervention and you know

specify how big your database is then you start an instance we give you 10 gig of storage and as your storage needs

your storage is scaling with your demand and you are only paying for the storage
that you are using of core and as your database needs grow we continue to add more 10 gig chunks to

10 * of what we have that other database engines so 64 terabytes of oltp database

challenge with traditional database right typically you write your scripts to take backups and then you move your
backups to another location for durability when you're taking backups there is a performance impact so we have
raised the bar there with Aurora there is no backup window in Aurora your data
is continuously getting backed up to s3 as you are inserting your data in the database so did database backups are
happening every time you do anything on the database so there is no performance impact while back up is happening it's
its normal course of operation and let's say as a developer you want you're
releasing a new software you want to take a manual snapshot you can still take that snapshot but that snapshot is
instantaneous because at that point we are just putting a marker in s3 saying
that at this point developer wanted a backup right so you hit the button that
take the database backup doesn't matter how big your database is you will get an

you want it to make an application release you want to take a backup you click a button and your database is
backed up no performance impact in terms
of monitoring monitoring has been made very simple with all audience databases as it is integrated with Amazon
CloudWatch which is our monitoring service you get access to 50 / 50 + OS
and system level metrics so you get access to cpu utilization storage memory process list
threads a whole bunch of metrics so even though you don't have direct access to
the database box you cannot ssh into the database box you get full view of what
is going on in your database in addition
you also get access to a database metrics for which you typically write
scripts right so you get access to number of database connections selects per second latency cache hit ratio and I

create alarms on top of these metrics as well so for example if you want to get

you can get automatically notified using cloud watch you can also integrate cloud
watch with your own ticketing systems so that you get tickets in your own ticketing system and you get alerted so
now you don't have to make maintain a stand-alone monitoring system which always breaks down or which is very
fragile so that comes integrated with Aurora security of course an important
topic for everybody just like other aw services we have very robust security model around Aurora in terms of
encryption at rest all of your data can be encrypted at rest both in s3 and on
the Aurora storage nodes and you can manage those keys and provide your own
keys through key management system if you wanted encryption in transit you can
connect to your aura instances over SSL Aurora is available in VPC you cannot
